article_title: Houston Methodist doctors strive to shine in star ratings
article_text:
Houston Methodist doctors strive to shine in star ratings Patients can now rate doctors with stars, comments

Photo: Brett Coomer, Staff ﻿Dr. Joshua Septimus is one of many doctors at Houston Methodist...

Taking consumer-driven health care to a new level, some patients in Houston can now rate their doctor just as they would a trendy new restaurant or used car.

article_metadata.description: Taking consumer-driven health care to a new level, some patients in Houston can now rate their doctor just as they would a trendy new restaurant or used car.  Earlier this month, Houston Methodist became one of a handful of hospitals in the country to post on its website the number of stars given by patients to 66 of its primary-care and orthopedic physicians.  A stated goal of the Affordable Care Act is more transparency, which means giving patients a stronger voice in their own care.  [...] how many consumers can objectively judge all that goes into their health care? said Dr. Setul Patel, an emergency medicine physician and president and CEO of Neighbors Emergency Center, a Pearland-based network of freestanding emergency rooms across the state.  In April, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services began publicly posting a five-star rating system for about 3,500 hospitals nationwide on its Hospital Compare website.  The number of stars reflects results of patient experience surveys on such things as staff communication and responsiveness, whether their room was clean and quiet, and if discharge instructions were clear.  Medicare also uses stars to evaluate nursing homes, some large group practices, home-health providers and dialysis centers.  Evan Marks, chief strategy officer for Healthgrades, admitted reviews on his site are not from verified patients, but they can still be valuable to consumers because they include education, areas of expertise, awards and past disciplinary actions.  "The thing that worries me is people might mistake more care for quality care," Septimus said of the potential for over-prescribing medications and ordering unneeded tests.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam
